author: Michael R Gates
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 29, 2019
review_content: I had an old Lexmark printer that I absolutely loved. The print quality was outstanding from the get-go, and I used it for everything from printing college term papers and business documents to printing artwork and photos. And in spite of its age--I bought it nearly 15 years ago--it was a real workhorse that just kept right on going no matter how much I threw at it. In fact, when I had to get rid of it, it still worked. So the problem wasn't the printer. The problem was Lexmark itself: the company apparently decided to get out of the printer business, and as of late 2018, I could no longer buy ink cartridges for my particular Lexmark model. So thus did my search for a new printer begin. And thus did enter this beauty, the HP OfficeJet Pro 8025. And I've gotta be honest: I'm not gonna miss my Lexmark. Not at all.The print quality of the HP OfficeJet Pro 8025 is every bit as good as that of my former beloved printer. In fact, despite HP's early intimations that this small-business printer shouldn't be considered a photo printer, it actually does a beautiful job of printing photos (both on photo paper and on regular paper too). But in addition to printing, the OfficeJet Pro 8025 can also scan, function as a copy machine, and send faxes (if you have a landline). And unlike my old Lexmark, the OfficeJet Pro 8025 offers multiple means of connectivity, so in addition to being direct-connected to a single computer, this HP printer can also be shared via wi-fi, Bluetooth, or an Ethernet connection.Besides the outstanding print quality, there are three other things I really like about HP's OfficeJet Pro 8025. First off, the setup was easy as pie. All I did was turn the printer on, install the ink cartridges, and then connect the printer to my internet-enabled computer, and--voil√†!--the printer's drivers were immediately downloaded and installed in a snap. It truly is a plug-and-play device. (I must also note that even though the printer has a built-in scanner, its scanner drivers do not interfere at all with the drivers or functionality of my high-definition Canon scanner, which I need for my professional art and photography projects. Even during installation, the HP software was not presumptuous and never assumed that I wanted the HP scanner to become my default.) Secondly, there are separate ink cartridges for each color, as opposed to the more common practice of having the three primary colors combined into a single cartridge. This means that if I use a lot of one color--say cyan, for example--during a particular project and the cyan ink runs out, all I do is buy a new cyan cartridge; I do not have to waste the yellow and magenta ink (or the money I paid for them) by ditching a tricolor cartridge just because the cyan ran out. And finally, I love the paper feed on this unit. It holds 250 sheets of paper--half a ream--and that's gonna be very convenient for my small-business purposes. (The feeder on my old printer couldn't hold more than 25 sheets, by the way, so printing college term papers or, later, long business reports could be a real pain.)Now, even the best things have an issue or two, and that's also true of the HP OfficeJet Pro 8025. In this case, it has to do with disabling the printer's built-in wi-fi should you choose not to use it. I decided that I did not want to use the printer's wi-fi or network options and would instead just direct-connect the printer, via USB, to my main office desktop computer. (I never print from either of my laptops, and my wife has her own printer.) Thus, I went into the printer's settings and turned off the wi-fi, did my printing chores for the day, and then powered everything down. However, when I came back later in the evening to show off my new printer and let my wife take a gander, the printer's wi-fi automatically turned back on when the unit powered up, and worse, an annoying light on the front of the printer started flashing to warn me of the wi-fi's not-connected status. So I manually turned the wi-fi off again, of course, but when I turned the printer off and then back on just to see what would happen, the wi-fi was again automatically enabled (along with its annoying status light). I spent a couple of hours doing some research to see if there is a way to disable the wi-fi permanently, but so far I've found nothing that works, so it looks like I will either have to manually disable the wi-fi every time I fire up the printer or I'll just have to learn to ignore the flashing wi-fi status light. Considering the printer's overall quality, though, this is a minor issue (and one I can live with).All in all, the HP OfficeJet Pro 8025 has thus far proven to be an outstanding printer. The printer's image quality is at a professional level, the unit is speedy, it's multifunctional (that is, it does more than just print), and it has many other features that make it perfect for a home office or a small business. Of course, its somewhat steep price reflects the fact that the printer is intended for small-business use, but nonetheless, I think I'd still also recommend it to anyone looking for a quality printer for basic home use. Since this unit can be connected to multiple computers via wi-fi, Bluetooth, or an Ethernet port on a network router, and since the printer has a large-capacity paper feed, the whole family could easily share. The HP OfficeJet Pro 8025 is smartly designed and made of high-quality materials, so I have no doubt it will stand up to the needs of either a small business or a big family.
title: Great Quality and Functionality for the Small Business or the Home Office

author: Scott W
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2020
review_content: I've owned a lot of printers over the years and watched all the printer/ink wars unfold. Basically with every ink printer on the market, they want to give you the printer next to free in hopes you'll spend a small fortune on ink. That's why you see some companies such as Lexmark folding on selling inkjet printers - margins are too low. And that's why you see such a low page count on the ink that comes with the printer - it's just enough to get you started so you have to buy more ink.So when purchasing a printer, all the silly little features they like to advertise are rather meaningless unless you really do need that touch screen or whatever. What matters is how well it prints (remember the days when a cell phone was measured by the quality of calls and not how well it took a picture?) and host costly the ink is over time. HP does a fair job on cost/page for their ink, although they try to sucker you into monthly services for ink and all kinds of crap. Apparently, gone are the days of just buying a printer and being able to print without big brother watching you print, analyzing your print habits and trying to sell you crap in your own home/business.My last printer was working fine and had about 7 years on it. What was becoming difficult was finding ink and driver support with Microshaft's poor Windows development. Around the same time, my father needed a printer and since I'm his tech support, I thought I'd buy 2 of the same kind to ease support. There's good and bad here.The good side of this printer is that it was very easy to set up. As with so many things now, there's a mobile app to set up the device. Yet another way to peer into your privacy, although few give it any consideration these days. I had the printer set up on wireless and connected to multiple PCs in under 20 minutes.The Windows software is a bit crappy and somewhat confusing in some places on what was going on. The first thing I wanted to do was turn off all the marketing crap (I don't need monthly ink service) and spying on me (HP does not need to know when and how much I print). They did keep some of that hidden well, so the average user won't just go ah, there are the spyware settings.Print quality on this printer is quite good. I've been very pleased with text being crisp and close to laser quality. I do not bother with photo printing at home considering the cost of photo paper and then the ink. Helpful hint here is to visit your local Walmart and get prints made much easier and likely cheaper unless you're doing a lot of scrapbooks.The worst downside on this printer is how slow it is to finally print something. I don't need to print every single day and apparently this printer gets a chip on its shoulder about it. When I do print, it goes into some kind of maintenance where it hums and acts like it is thinking hard about life. After 5 minutes or so, it finally spits out that precious page. I'm giving it the benefit of the doubt and guessing maybe it does something to the nozzles to prevent the ink from drying up and then has to do something to get started back up again. I'm rarely in a rush, so it's not the end of the world - just confusing when you don't know for sure what it is doing.For the price, this is about as good as it gets though. Once up and going, it's pretty hassle free. I'd recommend it and would likely purchase again.

I gave "Tech Support" five stars because I didn't need any.Cons: It automatically connects to the internet and send HP info or order ink when running low. I'm big on network security so I set my router to disallow internet connection. Also, I didn't install the printer app on smartphones or computers for the same reason.
title: THIS IS JUST GREAT!
